sect1.title: Overview and Purpose
sect1.para: This document describes the OpenSCADA DA NET interface.
This document currently is a work in progress so expect this specification to change.

sect3.title: About OpenSCADA
sect3.para: The OpenSCADA project aims to create a state of the art SCADA system.

sect3.title: About OpenSCADA DA
sect3.para: The DA (Data Access) interface of OpenSCADA focuses on accessing data.

sect3.title: About OpenSCADA DA NET
sect3.para: The OpenSCADA DA NET interface is the DA interface based on the protocol GMPP.

sect2.title: Purpose
sect2.para: This document specifies the OpenSCADA DA NET interface. It explains the basic prinicples of the interface, lists the messages exchanged between peers.

The information in this document is needed for creating a new implementation of the OpenSCADA DA NET interface. This might be necessary if you want to use a programming language which is currently not covered by the existing implementations.

sect2.title: Target audience
sect2.para: The target audience are people who are interested in creating their own implementation of the OpenSCADA DA NET interface. Although there are reference implementations it might be of interest for someone to create its own implementation (e.g. unsupported programming languages, license problems with open source licenses, etc).

sect1.title: The big picture
sect1.para: In order to understand what exactly the OpenSCADA DA NET interface is you will need to understand the big picture of the interfaces of OpenSCADA.
The idea for OpenSCADA is to be as independent and open as possible. So the target is that also for the interfaces of the different components it should be possible to exchange the interface itself.

sect2.title: Levels of interfacing
sect2.para:
In order to achieve this the interfaces are splitted up in two levels.
Level 0 interface
This is the lowest level. Normally neutral to the programming language used for implementing the interface.
A level 0 interface specification contains:
A communication layer
A description how the communication layer is used
Examples of Level 0 communication layers
GMPP
Corba
WebService
Examples of Level 0 communication layer descriptions
GMPP
Message specification
Corba
IDL of interface
WebService
WebService description
Level 1 interface
The level 1 interface is the programming language bound interface. So for example you might have a level 1 interface for progamming language you have (Java, C++, ...).
In some cases programming language dependant might not be correct. For example both Java and .NET are based on a virtual machine which executes the generated code. Both Java and .NET have different compilers that compile different programming languages to one VM-code they can reuse modules inside their framework.
For example Java (the framework) has Java (the programming language and Groovy. Creating an implementation in Java would allow Groovy to re-use the code since it is based on the same virtual machine. Also for .NET you have C# and VB.NET which share the same base. So an implementation in C# would be available in VB.NET.
To keep it simple the following sections will refer use programming language dependant but in some cases might mean framework dependant.
This results in two levels. One that is communication layer specific but programming language indepedant. And one that is communication layer independant but programming langage specific.

sect2.title: Level 0 implementations
sect2.para: A level 0 implementation is the merger of the both level 0 and level 1 interface. So by using the level 0 interface specification you implement the level 1 interface itself (e.g. you implement the Java interface by using the GMPP interface specification for OpenSCADA DA).
For example using the Level 0 interface OpenSCADA DA NET you implement the OpenSCADA DA Java interface.

sect2.title: Different sides
sect2.para: In most cases you will have differnt sides of an interface (e.g. OpenSCADA DA has a client and server side). There should be no difference at the level 0 interface (e.g. with Corba the IDL is the same for both server and client, only the client will use the Proxy classes whereas the server side implements the Corba interfaces).

sect3.title: You want to create a client application for OpenSCADA
sect3.para: When creating a client you normally will choose a programming language and stick with that.
So you don't care about the way of communication and select a level 1 interface which you use as interface to OpenSCADA.
For example you use OpenSCADA DA Java when developing your application. Later when running you select the OpenSCADA DA NET Java implementation.

sect3.title: You want to create a server application for OpenSCADA
sect3.para: Actually this is the same scenario as when creating client application. Based on your programming language you pick the level 1 interface and later when running let the user choose the level 0 implementation.

sect3.title: You have a server and want to access it
sect3.para: You have a server application and some client that want to access it.
Select what communication layer fits best for your needs and run both client and server with that level 0 implemenation.

For example server and client are written in Java and both use the OpenSCADA DA Java level 1 interface. You then choose OpenSCADA DA NET Java as level 0 implemenation because you need a client/server based protocol to tunnel through your firewall.
On the other side you could also choose OpenSCADA DA Corba Java because your like Corba more.
Or you choose OpenSCADA DA XXX Java because ...

sect3.title: You want to bring OpenSCADA to a new programming language
sect3.para: First check if you can re-use existing implementations. For example if you have implementations for Java and look for a Groovy interface you can reuse the Java interface since the base on the same virtual machine. The same is true for C# and VB.NET on the .NET Framework or on Mono.

If you cannot re-use an existing implemenation you need to take a three step approach:
Ensure that the communication layer of the level 0 interface exists for your environment or implement it.
Design a level 1 interface for your programming language. It should be close the already existing interface in order to aid others using it.
Implement the level 1 interface in your programming language by using the communication layer and specification of the level 0 interface.

sect3.title: When do I have to create a new level 0 interface
sect3.para: This question is a little bit harder to answer. Hopefully never because all level 0 interfaces should be provided by the OpenSCADA project itself. The plan is to have level 0 interfaces for: GMPP, Corba and WebServices. Which should cover most needs.
However there are also other interesting technologies which could be used as communication layer between OpenSCADA modules: Java RMI, ICE (http://www.zeroc.com/), and maybe a dozen more.

sect1.title: OpenSCADA DA NET
sect1.para: This section specifies that OpenSCADA DA NET interface.

sect2.title: Communication layer
sect2.para: As communication layer GMPP is used. For the description of GMPP itself see the GMPP protocol specification.

Since GMPP is used there are two distinct peers. A client and a server. The definition of client and server in GMPP are analogue to the definition of client and server in OpenSCADA. So the OpenSCADA client is also the GMPP client.

GMPP allows a session oriented communication. The GMPP session must be bound to the OpenSCADA DA session. When the GMPP session is closed (e.g. manual disconnect, broken link, etc) also the OpenSCADA session must be closed.
